awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Investigation of a Core-Shell Redox Catalyst Platform for Oxidative Dehydrogenation of Ethane
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will investigate the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethane to produce ethylene - a high volume chemical intermediate.  A novel approach is employed that utilizes a core-shell catalyst design in combination with a chemical looping redox cycle to achieve ODH without direct feed of oxygen.  The combined approach potentially eliminates a costly and energy-intensive process for separating oxygen from air, while also reducing carbon emissions.  The work will provide multi-disciplinary educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, as well as outreach activities to high school students and teachers for stimulating interest in STEM careers.

The core-shell redox catalyst is both an active catalyst and an effective lattice oxygen ion donor for ethane ODH in a chemical-looping scheme.  The work plan tests three key hypotheses: 1) Chemically and structurally compatible primary (cobalt/iron) oxides and perovskites can be assembled into a stable core-shell arrangement for ethane ODH under a cyclic redox mode; 2) The surface properties of the core-shell redox catalyst can be tailored by tuning the metal cation oxidation state and defect structure of the mixed ionic-electronic conductor (MIEC) shell, rendering a highly effective catalyst for ethane ODH in the absence of gaseous oxidants; 3) Ethane ODH reaction occurs primarily on the perovskite surface via homolytic C-H bond cleavage through a modified Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. To test these hypotheses, phase-compatible core and shell materials will be identified and then assembled into core-shell particles.  The effects of perovskite A-site and B-site substitutions on ODH activity and selectivity will be investigated and correlated to the defect structure and cation oxidation state of the shell material. Kinetic and mechanistic aspects will be investigated over pellets and thin films replicating the core-shell and shell structures using in-situ Raman and FT-IR/DRIFTS, a molecular beam reactor coupled with an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer, and pulse isotope studies. The studies will potentially result in fundamentally new materials and schemes that can significantly improve the efficiency for ethylene production from natural gas while reducing emissions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Ethylene, with an annual demand of over 150 million metric tons each year, is an important building block for the chemical industry. Commercial ethylene production technologies, based on steam cracking of alkanes, are both energy and carbon intensive. The recent increase in shale gas production has opened up exciting opportunities for ethylene production via oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of wet (C2+) natural gas components. However, existing ODH catalysts require pure oxygen which is both costly and energy intensive to produce. This project investigated a unique core-shell redox catalyst that is both an active catalyst and an effective lattice oxygen (O2-) donor for oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethane. This allows in-situ oxygen separation and ethane ODH to efficiently produce ethylene via a chemical looping ? ODH (CL-ODH) scheme. Using such a redox catalyst, high ethylene selectivity and yield as well as low CO2/NOx emissions can potentially be achieved in absence of gaseous oxygen. This project has led to exciting scientific findings with an excellent potential to generate significant practical impacts:

 

Intellectual Merit: Redox catalyst design and synthesis strategies as well as the underlying reaction mechanisms have been thoroughly investigated in this project. The project has enabled us to develop a new class of mixed oxide @ molten salt redox catalysts for CL-ODH of ethane. We have obtained in-depth mechanistic insights for many specific oxide ? salt combinations and the generalized principles have helped to guide the catalyst optimization efforts for the production of ethylene. It is also possible to apply the same principles to produce other light olefins such as propylene and butadiene. The resulting mixed oxide @ molten salt redox catalyst platform is highly unique, flexible, and scientifically intriguing. We have also successfully prepared thin film model catalysts, which have allowed us to use surface science tools to further probe the reaction pathways and the active sites on the surface. This research project is highly interdisciplinary given that it utilizes the knowledge in areas such as catalysis, surface science, chemical looping, reaction engineering, process engineering, and materials science/engineering. The knowledge generated from this study directly benefits these disciplines and pushes the boundary for heterogeneous catalysis.

 

Broader Impact: The redox catalysts in the CL-ODH approach combines the advantage of both chemical looping (in terms of in-situ oxygen separation and process intensification) and heterogeneous catalysis (in terms of high selectivity to value-added chemical products). Combining the function of oxygen storage/release and catalysis enables (air) separation integrated with catalytic reactions, allowing 80+% energy and CO2 savings for ethylene production based on our recent studies. From a practical standpoint, we have achieved very high olefin yields (~75%), exceeding most, if not all, the ODH catalysts reported to date. This project also enabled us to explore other chemical looping catalysis reactions for chemical production related to CL-ODH redox catalysts. Some very interesting preliminary results are being generated. These include oxidative cracking of naphtha, oxidative coupling of methane, and oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbeneze and cumene. Intensifying the production of these olefinic products can potentially reduce the CO2 emissions from existing industrial processes by a few hundred million tons each year. This project has also generated many high impact publications and provided training opportunities for mulitple undergraduate and graduate researchers.

 


Last Modified: 02/17/2022
Modified by: Fanxing Li

Images (1 of )
  • Bottom Left: Simplified Schematic of the Chemical looping - Oxidative Dehydrogenation (CL-ODH) approach; Top and Middle Right: Redox Catalyst Performance for ethane CL-ODH; Bottom Right: Projected process performance in terms of emission reduction and exergy loss minimization.
    Vasudev Haribal and Fanxing Li
    Creative Commons
    Fanxing Li
    Efficient Ethylene Production via Chemical Looping Oxidative Dehydrogenation
  • CL-ODH reaction pathway on a perovskite: @ carbonate redox catalyst. Peroxide formation from (a) Fe4+ to Fe3+ and (b) Fe3+ to Fe2+ during the ODH step, with enthalpy changes labeled; (c) Proposed reaction pathways for ODH and re-oxidation steps.
    Yunfei Gao and Fanxing Li
    Creative Commons
    Fanxing Li
    Schematic of the CL-ODH Reaction Pathway
